2 #include "definitions.h"

4 #include <twizy_wheel_encoder/WheelEncoder.h>

6 namespace twizy_wheel_encoder {
7 
8 Sensor::Sensor(const char *topic_name, const Parameters &params,
9  const Parameters::Side &side)
10  : params_(params), side_(side), publisher(topic_name, &msg_) {
11  msg_.speed = 0.0;
12 }
13 
14 void Sensor::initialize(twizy_wheel_encoder::NodeHandle &nh, int pin,
15  void (*calls_tick)()) {
16  pinMode(pin, INPUT_PULLUP);
17  attachInterrupt(digitalPinToInterrupt(pin), calls_tick, RISING);
18 
19  nh.advertise(publisher);
20 
21  last_time_ = millis();
22 }
23 
24 void Sensor::publish(const ros::Time &stamp) {
25  unsigned long time = millis();
26 
27  msg_.header.frame_id = side_.frame_id;
28  msg_.header.stamp = stamp;
29  // If a long time has passed without an encoder tick, without using min()
30  // the speed would get stuck at whatever the last value was. We would prefer
31  // if the published speed would instead be reduced, preferably after a while
32  // to zero. This way of doing things ensures that speed measurements will be
33  // continuous when slowing down, but it would be nice if the measurements
34  // would approach zero faster when encoder ticks stop coming. Integrating
35  // the speed as it is now the position will tend to infinity, even after the
36  // car stops (\int_1^\infty \frac{1}{x} \dd{x} = \infty).
37  msg_.speed = min(msg_.speed, params_.sensitivity / (time - last_time_));
38  msg_.covariance = params_.covariance;
39  publisher.publish(&msg_);
40 }
41 
42 void Sensor::tick() {
43  unsigned long time = millis();
44  // Really basic way of calculating speed... Something more fancy can be done
45  // here for sure
46  msg_.speed = params_.sensitivity / (time - last_time_);
47  last_time_ = time;
48 }
49 
50 } // namespace twizy_wheel_encoder
